newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Southeast spot power pressured by warmer temp.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Southeast spot power pressured by warmer temp.

text.p: Wholesale electricity prices in the southeastern U.S. were pressured Thursday by forecasts of temperatues in the winter moderating from recent winter-like lows.

"The milder temperature is the main driving force," said a Southeast power marketer, adding that some regional utilities planned to restore operation by this weekend to some generating units that were idled for seasonal maintenance.

For Friday, the Southeast excluding Florida was predicted to receive peak temperatures in 40s-60s Fahrenheit and off-peak temperatures in 20s-40s. The Florida pennisula was expected to enjoy mild temperatures in the 70s-80s during the day and 50s-60s in the evening.
"We had pretty flat loads today. This weekend, there's a very likelihood we'll have rain and clouds," said a Florida trader.

Among Florida utilities, peak, firm electricity scheduled for Friday was valued near $24.00 a megawatt hour (MWh) and for Saturday near $22.00-$23.00, compared with Wednesday's $23.50 quote for Thursday.
Peak, firm power for Friday delivery into northwestern portion of Tennessee Valley Authority's (TVA) territory were pegged near $23.00, down from Wednesday's $25.00-$28.00.
Firm, next-day power for delivery into northwestern TVA during Friday's light load hours was discussed near $15.00, compared with a range of $14.50-$15.00 on Wednesday.
TVA was reportedly offering peak, next-day electricity at $27.00-$28.00.
At the Georgia/Florida border, firm, peak power prices for Friday was quoted near $26.00 with offers talked as high as the low-$30s.
Today's values at the Ga./Fla. border compared with Wednesday's $26.00-$28.00.
Firm, off-peak at the Ga./Fla. border for next-day delivery remained flat in the $16.00-$18.00 range.
Peak, firm power scheduled for Thursday's delivery in the Florida pennisula ended near $23.50 after talked as high as $28.00 in early trading, traders and marketers said.
